content: Several tax options have been proposed to finance health care reform, including restricting itemized deductions for high-income taxpayers, modifying the tax exclusion for employer-provided health care, increasing taxes on alcoholic beverages, and imposing an excise tax on non-diet sweetened beverages. The House Ways and Means Committee has suggested funding the reform through a surtax on high-income individuals, which was passed by the House on November 14, 2009 (H.R. 3962). The House Ways and Means Committee proposed financing health care reform through a surtax on high-income individuals, passed by the House on November 14, 2009 (H.R. 3962). The Senate Finance Committee reported S. 1796 with an excise tax on insurers for high-cost plans. President Obama's compromise proposal, based on H.R. 3590, includes changes to revenue provisions, delaying the tax on high-cost employer plans to 2018 and raising exemption thresholds. The new plan proposed by the Administration would modify H.R. 3590 from 2013 to 2018, increasing the exemption threshold for the tax. It includes a 3.8% tax on unearned income for high-income households. The House passed H.R. 3590 and H.R. 4872 on March 22, 2010, with the President signing them into law shortly after. Detailed revenue estimates of the different versions show varying effects on behavior and income distribution. The tax proposals in the new plan have varying effects on behavior and income distribution. Taxes may fall more heavily on higher-income taxpayers (progressive), equally on all taxpayers (proportional), or lower-income taxpayers (regressive). For example, limiting itemized deductions and high adjusted gross incomes affects top income brackets, while limiting health-related exclusions impacts middle-income brackets more proportionally. Excise taxes tend to be regressive, impacting lower-income classes more. The distributional analysis in the report focuses on the regressive nature of excise taxes, which disproportionately affect lower-income classes. Despite this regressive revenue source, the overall health care reform proposals are likely to benefit lower-income families. The report reviews various revenue raisers proposed by the House, Senate, and President Obama, as well as other financing proposals. The final legislation's most significant revenue raiser is the increased excise taxes. The final legislation's main revenue raisers include an increased Medicare tax, a fee on health insurance providers, a tax on employer health insurance premiums, and a fee on branded drugs. These health-related provisions account for about 90% of revenues over a 10-year period. In 2019, revenue raisers include Medicare tax, Cadillac tax, health insurance fees, drug fee, and biofuel provision.
